Language Analysis: The expert may have employed language analysis to verify the authenticity of the claim. They could have examined the wording and structure of the claim to assess its accuracy and credibility.
Fact: checking: The expert may have conducted fact-checking to verify the claim. They could have researched the Congressional Budget Office's report on ObamaCare and analyzed whether it actually concluded that it would cost the U.S. more than 800,000 jobs.
Source Evaluation: The expert may have evaluated the credibility and reliability of the sources cited in the claim. They could have assessed the reputation and expertise of the Congressional Budget Office to determine if their conclusion on ObamaCare and job loss can be trusted.
Cross: referencing: The expert may have cross-referenced the claim with other reputable sources or studies to validate its authenticity. They could have looked for similar findings or conclusions in other independent research or reports to confirm the accuracy of the claim.
